title: Dose Response Study of Exercise for Age-related Cognitive Changes
description_brief: This is a randomized, 26-week study of supervised exercise assessing three doses of exercise in sedentary individuals 65 years of age and over with age-related cognitive changes. A total of 100 subjects (n=25 in each of four groups) will be randomized to a non-aerobic control group, 75 minutes, 150 minutes, or 225 minutes a week of moderate intensity aerobic exercise spread over 3 to 5 days a week for 26 weeks. These exercise doses represent 50%, 100%, or 150% of the recommended exercise dose. Participants will be directly supervised during all exercise sessions for the first two months after which direct supervision will occur during at least one session a week. This is intended to provide increased flexibility while also maintaining direct contact with the participant to enhance adherence. Aerobic fitness, physical function, and cognition will be assessed at baseline and 26 weeks to examine the dose-response relationships.

groups.title: Nonexercise Control Group
groups.description: Nonexercise control group: Participants randomized to the nonexercise control group will be asked to maintain their current level of physical activity during the 26-week active study period. They will perform outcome assessments and receive the same telephone checks as the exercise group at baseline, 26 and 52 weeks. The purpose of including a non-exercise control group is to allow adequate comparisons with the low, medium and high exercise dose groups on changes in cognitive and physiologic outcome measures.

groups.title: Aerobic Exercise Group 1
groups.description: Aerobic Exercise Group 1: The 50% group will perform 75 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise spread over 3 days.

groups.title: Aerobic Exercise Group 2
groups.description: Aerobic Exercise Group 2: The 100% group will perform 150 minutes a week of exercise over 3 - 5 days

groups.title: Aerobic Exercise Group 3
groups.description: Aerobic Exercise Group 3: The 150% group will perform 225 minutes a week of exercise over 4 - 5 days.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Participants were recruited as a convenience sample of volunteers through print and online advertising, community talks, and existing databases of individuals willing to be in research studies Participants had to be at least 65, sedentary or underactive a, and free of cognitive impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Verbal Memory
outcomeMeasures.description:
Verbal Memory is a latent derived variable derived estimated mean. The reported latent means for this trial are created from the well-known neuropsychological tests: Logical Memory, Delayed Logical Memory, Selective Reminding Task - Free Recall Total, Boston Naming Test.

Latent variables cannot be measured directly but are derived from a theory-driven confirmatory factor analysis in a structural equation model framework. The latent scores are centered around a mean of 0 and standardized so each value represents a fraction of the standard deviation. There are no limits to the scores. Positive number indicate improved performance.Negative numbers indicate worsening performance.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Healthy older adults without measurable cognitive decline who did not meet recommended daily activity levels.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Maximal Oxygen Consumption
outcomeMeasures.description: Maximal Oxygen consumption (VO2 max) is the standard, quantitative measure of aerobic fitness. The physiologic range of scores is approximately 3.5 milliliters of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute (ml/kg/min) to approximately 90 (ml/kg/min). Higher numbers indicate greater fitness and positive change indicates increasing fitness. Lower number indicate worse fitness

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Physical Performance Test
outcomeMeasures.description: The Physical Performance Test is a 9-item measure of physical function. The range of scores is 0-34. Higher numbers indicate better physical function. Positive change indicates improving function. Negative change indicates decreasing function.

otherEvents.notes: Irregular heart rate, angina or EKG change typically seen during cardiopulmonary testing. Events may have been discovered at baseline screening and not attributable to intervention
Coughing or upper respiratory infection made worse by exercise
Other infection considered to be exacerbated by exercise

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is supervised aerobic exercise (three dose levels vs a non-aerobic control) delivered to sedentary adults ≥65 to examine effects on aerobic fitness, physical function, and cognition. This is a behavioral/physiologic intervention intended to improve cognitive performance rather than a biologic or small-molecule agent targeting Alzheimer pathology, and it does not primarily target neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search1turn0search7

Act: Key trial details extracted from the description — title: "Dose Response Study of Exercise for Age-related Cognitive Changes"; randomized, 26-week; 4 arms: non-aerobic control, 75, 150, 225 min/week of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise; primary/assessed outcomes include cognition (and fitness/physical function). The same or highly similar study is reported in the literature as a community-based, pilot RCT of aerobic exercise dose on cognition. citeturn0search1

Reflect: Given the intervention type (exercise) and stated aims (to examine dose–response effects on cognition), the correct category is "cognitive enhancer." This classification fits the provided category definitions: the trial tests a non-pharmacologic means to improve cognitive function without an explicit disease-modifying biologic or small-molecule mechanism, and it is not focused on treating neuropsychiatric symptoms. Supporting evidence that aerobic exercise is studied as a cognitive-enhancing intervention in older adults is available in RCT and review literature. citeturn0search1turn0search4turn0search7

Web search results (sources used): 1) "Dose-response of Aerobic Exercise on Cognition: A Community-Based, Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial" (PubMed) — matches the trial design (no-change control; 75/150/225 min/week; 26 weeks). citeturn0search1 2) Systematic reviews/meta-analyses on exercise dose and cognition in older adults (summaries showing dose-response and cognitive benefits of aerobic/resistance exercise). citeturn0search4turn0search7

Notes/uncertainty: No drug or biologic is involved, so drug/placebo fields are empty. Classification assumes "cognitive enhancer" includes behavioral exercise interventions aiming to improve cognition rather than pharmacologic disease modification.
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is a behavioral aerobic exercise program (three dose levels vs non-aerobic control) delivered to sedentary adults ≥65 intended to improve cognition and fitness. Exercise-related cognitive benefits are most commonly attributed to increased cardiorespiratory fitness and downstream effects on neurotrophic factors, synaptic plasticity, and neuroprotection (e.g., BDNF-mediated effects). Given this, the most specific CADRO match is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. citeturn0search1turn1search0

Act: Extracted trial details — title: "Dose Response Study of Exercise for Age-related Cognitive Changes" (pilot RCT/TEAM, NCT01129115); 26 weeks; 4 arms: no-change control, 75, 150, 225 min/week moderate-intensity aerobic exercise; primary/assessed outcomes include cognition, cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2 peak) and physical function. No drug/biologic is used. Based on the intervention and hypothesized mechanisms (fitness → neurotrophic/synaptic changes), I assign: M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. citeturn0search1

Reflect: This classification fits the description because the trial tests a non-pharmacologic cognitive-enhancing intervention whose plausible mechanisms (fitness increases, BDNF changes, neurogenesis/synaptic plasticity) map best to synaptic plasticity/neuroprotection. If one required a narrower label focused strictly on neurogenesis, E) Neurogenesis could also be argued (exercise promotes hippocampal neurogenesis), but M is broader and better captures synaptic/neuroprotective pathways invoked by aerobic exercise. The trial does not target amyloid/tau/inflammation specifically, so other CADRO categories are less appropriate. Supporting evidence linking exercise to cognitive gains and increased BDNF/fitness-mediated effects is shown below. citeturn0search1turn1search0turn1search2

Web search results used (key sources): 1) Dose-Response of Aerobic Exercise on Cognition: A Community-Based, Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial (full text, PMC) — trial matches design and outcomes described. citeturn0search1 2) PubMed entry for the same dose-response aerobic exercise RCT. citeturn0search0 3) Systematic review & meta-analysis: Exercise training alters resting BDNF concentration in older adults (shows exercise increases BDNF, a mediator of synaptic plasticity). citeturn1search0 4) Study/meta-analyses on exercise intensity and memory in older adults (links fitness increases to memory improvements; mechanisms remain under study). citeturn1search2 5) Studies showing acute/chronic exercise can raise BDNF in older adults and people with AD, supporting a neurotrophic/synaptic mechanism. citeturn1search6turn1search5
